review.title: Nondeterministic fuzzy automata
review.abstract: Fuzzy automata have long been accepted as a generalization of nondeterministic finite automata. A closer examination, however, shows that the fundamental property---nondeterminism---in nondeterministic finite automata has not been well embodied in the generalization. In this paper, we introduce nondeterministic fuzzy automata with or without $\el$-moves and fuzzy languages recognized by them. Furthermore, we prove that (deterministic) fuzzy automata, nondeterministic fuzzy automata, and nondeterministic fuzzy automata with $\el$-moves are all equivalent in the sense that they recognize the same class of fuzzy languages.

metadata.title: Nondeterministic fuzzy automata

sections.text: Fuzzy automata have long been accepted as a generalization of non-deterministic finite automata. However, a closer examination shows that the basic property - non-determinism - in non-deterministic finite automata is not well anchored in generalization. In this essay, we present non-deterministic fuzzy automata with or without -moves and blurred languages that they recognize. Furthermore, we prove that (deterministic) blurred automata, non-deterministic blurred automata and non-deterministic blurred automata with -moves are all equivalent in the sense that they recognize the same class of blurred languages. Keywords: fuzzy automata, non-deterministic finite blurred automata, non-deterministic blurred automata with -moves, blurred language

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The finite automata (also referred to as finite state automata or finite state machines) are therefore probably best known as Q 101 computer-aided machines and are used for modeling many systems in practice. Automata theory is closely related to formal language theory, since the automata are often classified by the class of formal languages they are able to recognize [15]. Finite automation gives a finite representation of a regular language that can be a finite set. It is widely known that finite automata are significant in many different areas, including computer science, linguistics, electrical engineering, philosophy, and biology. To address the inaccuracy in modeling some systems, blurred automata, and blurred languages, a meaningful extension of classical automata and formal language theory has been proposed. The mathematical formulation of blurred automata was first proposed by Wee in 1967 [36]. The basic idea of the formulation of the state, as opposed to a classical state, is one that can be switched to a menstrual state.

sections.heading: 2. Preliminaries
sections.text: In this section, we briefly recall a few basic facts about fuzzy sets, fuzzy automata, and fuzzy A languages. Let's start with the term fuzzy sets initiated by Zadeh [40]. Suppose X is a universal set A, or rather a fuzzy subset A of X, defined by a function assigned to each element x of a value A (x). In light of this fact, a fuzzy subset of X can be described as a generalization of the characteristic function associated with a crisp subset of X. The value A (x) characterizes the degree of membership of x in A. In light of this, a fuzzy subset of X can be described as a distribution of possibilities to X.We denote from F (X) the set of all fuzzy subsets of X, and from P (X) the power set of X.

sections.heading: 3. Nondeterministic fuzzy automata
sections.text: In literature, the concept of (deterministic) fuzzy automata has long been accepted as a generalization of non-deterministic finite automata. To see this, let's review the definition of nondeterministic finite automata. Indeed, it is so. Let's point out that the basic property - nondeterministic finite automata - in nondeterministic finite automata has not been fully embodied in generalization.

sections.heading: 5. Equivalences
sections.text: It is well known that for any non-deterministic finite automation with or without motion, there is an equivalent finite automation Q = q = q (q = q = q), so that both accept the same language [15]. In this section, we would like to apply this equivalence to a non-deterministic fuzzy automation M = q (q = q = q), which shows that non-deterministic fuzzy automata without motion and deterministic fuzzy automata accept the same class of fuzzy automata. Theorem 1. For each non-deterministic fuzzy automation M, there is first a deterministic fuzzy automation M ² s, so that L (M) = L (M ² s).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In the paper, we have examined non-deterministic fuzzy automata with non-determinism by introducing non-deterministic fuzzy automata and non-deterministic fuzzy automata with -moves. As the relationship between deterministic finite automata, non-deterministic fuzzy automata with -moves and non-deterministic finite automata with -moves has shown, deterministic fuzzy automata, non-deterministic fuzzy automata and non-deterministic fuzzy automata with -moves are equivalent in that they accept the same class of fuzzy languages. As an application of non-deterministic fuzzy automata, we are currently using them to model and specify non-deterministic fuzzy systems for discrete events.

metadata.abstractText: Fuzzy automata have long been accepted as a generalization of nondeterministic finite automata. A closer examination, however, shows that the fundamental property—nondeterminism—in nondeterministic finite automata has not been well embodied in the generalization. In this paper, we introduce nondeterministic fuzzy automata with or without -moves and fuzzy languages recognized by them. Furthermore, we prove that (deterministic) fuzzy automata, nondeterministic fuzzy automata, and nondeterministic fuzzy automata with -moves are all equivalent in the sense that they recognize the same class of fuzzy languages.
